{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3457198,"name":"Poyraz Aygül","username":"poaygul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/poaygul/{size}/235100_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-10T07:37:25.055Z","cooked":"

Last season we had a constant problem with our CAN bus, devices disconnecting and reconnecting. We had to use rev hardware client to recognize and hotfix these issues.

Tho we fixed the reliability problem, we want to identify which CAN device is disconnected on our dashboard by software.

Is this possible by any way, if it is can you provide any code?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":2,"updated_at":"2024-12-10T07:37:25.055Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":38,"reads":118,"readers_count":117,"score":228.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":476383,"topic_slug":"can-bus-control-by-software","display_username":"Poyraz Aygül","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60521,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7840 Driver, Electrical, Strategy"},"post_url":"/t/can-bus-control-by-software/476383/1","custom_user_title":"7840 Driver, Electrical, Strategy","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3457200,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-10T08:00:14.463Z","cooked":"

First thing I’m going to say is that it MAY be possible, but it’s not just a code problem to do that. Your wiring guys need to be on board too.

CAN, as you’re aware, is generally constructed as a single bus, two wires, all the devices on that bus between the start point and the end point (a terminating resistor). Lose one device, the entire bus goes down. With the entire bus being down, you can’t get any signals back. The ONLY way to have this work properly would be for there to be terminating resistors after or in every single device… which could have other issues. I’ll defer to the CAN experts on if that will work. If it would work do do that then you’d have a troubleshooting code that knew the order of devices on the bus and flagged the first one that wasn’t responding as “confirmed issue” and anything beyond that as “broken chain, check later”.

But, there’s another wiring option for CAN: The star topology. There are a few teams that use that instead. In that case, each controller (or each X controllers) is on a single shorter stub of CAN, all of which originate from a hub (and all stubs have a terminating resistor). It’s not quite as easy to wire, but it does allow you to figure out what’s connected by what’s responding–and obviously if a device that was responding stops responding, it’s been disconnected. That’s a simpler troubleshooting code, I think: it’s literally “if no data from device, flag as broken”.

I want to say there’s a bit of a hybrid option, don’t recall the name but someone is selling a CAN splitter that makes two CAN busses instead of just one. You could set that up and you’d get a half-answer as to what went wrong… but that’s more “limit where to troubleshoot” than anything else.
